title: Has the Internet made writers of us all? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, and kids are the biggest gainers of us all! Those of us who just had a smattering in English, have gradually shed our shyness and started writing. First, it's simple shares... then simple words... then broken half-liners of comments... then tentative full liners... then more correct one liners... then more confident two liners... then almost suddenly a long para of angry blast:):) Internet has given us ready-to-use content; reproducible analysis; copyable style and a huge graffiti space to write on. There's a platform for every taste, intent, caliber and purpose.  Internet excites you, provokes you, tickles you, invites you, seduces you, angers you, and eggs you to come out of your shell.

Yes. Arthur C. Clarke made a wonderful case for dividing word-gatherers into two groups. There's writers, and there's Writers. The first, with the little w (and that's the majority population of the internet) are amateurs. The ones with the big W, though, they're pros; they write for a living. There's a whole spectrum of quality, not all are articulate. I've seen failures of grammar in professional work, and I've seen poetry in tweets. So, yes, from its need for us to communicate using text, the internet has made writers of us all. And, occasionally, it has made Writers.

Yes, the internet has made everyone writers but many people bemoan the fact that the terse style of writing damages the art of writing.  I tend to agree for those attempting to write on mobile phones.  The LOL, BRB and BFF shorthand for everything is a step in the wrong direction.  Of course, as a writer, I enjoy the "long form".  Best wishes!

No. All it has done is make us notice how badly we write. My native language is Spanish, and a walk around the forums and internet blogs make me very sad. Misspellings and inability to express themselves correctly announce the end of a world full of ignorant people, which makes me think that we probably deserve it.

At a most basic level a 'writer' is a person who writes something, perhaps regularly, perhaps well, but most often the 'writer' writes for others to read. I think that the internet has made it so a hugely-greater percentage of people write with the hope or intention that others will read what they have written. This post, a case and point.
Depends on what you mean by writers. Just as the telephone hasn't turned us all into orators, the Internet hasn't made us all writers. Go read a 200+ comment thread on a Youtube video to verify this.
Basically we all are writers, You wrote the question and I am writing the answer . So internet has really help all potential writers but also made some people think that they can write too.
Oh my. What is has done is help to formulate the grammar police for those who wish they were. And if nothing else, it shows how important an education in English language skills still needs to be.
Just like buying a DSLR makes us a photographer.
